name: Simple Feedback Loop
description: A basic model demonstrating positive and negative feedback loops in biological systems. Perfect for learning the fundamentals of biological regulation.

components.name: Signal
components.description: Initial trigger that starts the process

components.name: Protein A
components.description: Activator protein that promotes Protein B

components.name: Protein B
components.description: Response protein that can activate or inhibit

components.name: Protein C
components.description: Inhibitor protein that provides negative feedback

connections.description: Positive feedback: Protein B activates itself
Protein B activates inhibitor Protein C
Negative feedback: Protein C inhibits Protein A

instructions: This model shows two types of feedback loops:
1. Positive Feedback: Protein B activates itself (amplification)
2. Negative Feedback: Protein C inhibits Protein A (regulation)
• Run the simulation with Signal ON
• Watch how Protein B amplifies itself
• Notice how Protein C eventually slows things down
• Turn Signal OFF and see what happens
• This is how your body maintains balance (homeostasis)!

quiz.question: What is positive feedback?
options: When a process slows itself down

quiz.question: What is negative feedback?
options: When a process regulates and slows itself
When a process creates new components

quiz.question: Why is negative feedback important in biology?
options: It helps maintain balance and stability

teacherNotes: This model simplifies feedback loops for middle school understanding.
Real examples: body temperature, blood sugar, hormone levels
Students can experiment with turning signal on/off
Extension: Compare to thermostats and other everyday examples
